sen.j: 藤井 直明（ふじい なおあき、享保5年（1720年） - 明和4年8月22日 (旧暦)（1767年9月14日））は、江戸時代中期の尊王論者。
sen.e: Naoaki FUJII (1720 - September 14, 1767) was an imperialist, who lived during the middle of the Edo period.

sen.e: In 1758 when Shikibu TAKENOUCHI was arrested in the Horeki Incident, he left Kyoto and went to Edo (present Tokyo), where he called himself Umon and lodged with Daini YAMAGATA.

sen.j: 1766年（明和3年）の明和事件では山県大弐、竹内式部とともに捕らえられ、翌1767年（明和4年）『兵書雑談』の内容に不敬があったとして打首・獄門の刑に処せられた（牢死説もある）。
sen.e: In 1766 when the Meiwa Incident occurred, he was arrested together with Daini YAMAGATA and Shikibu TAKENOUCHI, and the next year, 1767, he was decapitated and exposed at a prison gate for the great impropriety in the content of his book Heisho zatsudan" (a talk about The Art of War).

sen.j: 直明のひ孫である藤井多門が岩倉具視と親交を深め、直明の思想が明らかとなり、明治維新後、正四位が贈られた。
sen.e: Owing to a friendly tie that Naoaki's great grand son Tamon FUJII deepened with Tomomi IWAKURA, Naoaki's thought came to be recognized and after the Meiji Restoration, he was posthumously given Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank).
